qas.question: What piece of Bach's did Chopin take inspiration for his preludes?
Who suggested that Chopin's preludes were not intended to be played as a group?
What was described as "the beginning of studies" by Schumann?
What inspired Chopin for his preludes?
Kenneth Hamilton suggests that the preludes may not have been meant as a group but rather as what?

answers.text: generic preludes to others of his pieces

qas.question: Who did a recording where Étude Op. 10 No. 5. follows relude Op. 28 No. 7?

context: <a2_0>The preludes<a2_0/>, many of which are very brief (some consisting of simple statements and developments of a single theme or figure), were described by Schumann as "the beginnings of studies". Inspired by <a3_0>J.S. Bach's <a0_0>The Well-Tempered Clavier<a3_0/><a0_0/>, Chopin's preludes move up the circle of fifths (rather than Bach's chromatic scale sequence) to create a prelude in each major and minor tonality. The preludes were perhaps not intended to be played as a group, and may even have been used by him and later pianists as <a4_0>generic preludes to others of his pieces<a4_0/>, or even to music by other composers, as <a1_0>Kenneth Hamilton<a1_0/> suggests: he has noted a recording by <a5_0>Ferruccio Busoni<a5_0/> of 1922, in which the Prelude Op. 28 No. 7 is followed by the Étude Op. 10 No. 5.
